title: SpaceX Completes Cryogenic Testing for Upgraded Super Heavy Booster
summary: SpaceX has successfully completed cryogenic proof testing on its Super Heavy V3 booster, a critical step toward the next Starship flight. The testing occurred at Massey's Test Site in Starbase, Texas, over six days, involving four cycles of loading super-cold liquid nitrogen to simulate the stresses of actual rocket fuel. This test is significant because the previous booster assigned to the Starship V3 mission failed during a pressure test in November, leading to its destruction. The new booster passed, and it will now be equipped with 33 upgraded Raptor 3 engines and three grid fins for improved controllability during descent. SpaceX plans to conduct further tests, including a static fire, with the goal of launching the Starship V3 before the end of March. This flight is part of a series of test flights aimed at advancing SpaceX's capabilities for ambitious missions, such as orbital refueling and trips to the Moon and Mars. NASA is monitoring progress closely, as Starship is integral to the Artemis lunar program for landing astronauts on the Moon.

the upgraded booster version for SpaceX's Starship rocket, designed for more thrust and reliability
advanced rocket engines with higher thrust and integrated components for better performance
a process where rockets refuel in space to enable longer missions to distant locations
NASA's initiative to return humans to the Moon, with Starship as a potential lander

background_read: SpaceX, founded by Elon Musk, is a private aerospace company developing reusable rockets like Starship to reduce space travel costs. The Super Heavy booster is the first stage of Starship, providing initial thrust. Cryogenic testing involves exposing rocket components to extreme cold to ensure they can handle the temperatures of liquid methane and oxygen used as propellants. The Artemis program is NASA's effort to land astronauts on the Moon by the late 2020s, relying on commercial partners like SpaceX. Test flights are iterative, with failures informing design improvements for safety and performance.
Article_Structure: Main Points: SpaceX completed cryogenic testing on the Super Heavy V3 booster, moving closer to the Starship V3 test flight. The test involved liquid nitrogen cycles to assess structural integrity, following a previous booster failure. Upgrades include Raptor 3 engines and three grid fins for better control. Purpose: To report on a key milestone in SpaceX's Starship development, highlighting progress toward ambitious space missions like lunar landings. Evidence Evaluation: The article cites SpaceX's social media announcement and describes test procedures, providing credible technical details. Author Credibility: Ars Technica is a reputable science and tech news source with over 25 years of experience. Methodology: Information is gathered from SpaceX updates and on-site reporting, offering a factual account of events.

perspectives.description: Highlights SpaceX's iterative testing and design improvements for safer, more capable rockets.
